body: Acting on the recommendation of the Science Council of Germany, the DAI launched a project to develop a digitization strategy in 2017. It was created with the adaptation of the open source software ATOM of the service iDAI.archives. The photo libraries of the DAI are continuously digitized, as are the archives and the archives. However, especially valuable books and the publications published since its founding in 1829 by the DAI are being digitized to protect the existing status and to improve accessibility.

title: Service for Partner Institutions
body: Numerous museums and institutions use the information infrastructures to systematically digitalize and index their archives. These include German photo libraries and archives as well as international antiquities authorities and museums. Together we are working to advance digitalization standards, optimized workflows and a better information infrastructure for the cultural heritage of antiquity.

title: Ongoing and completed projects
body: In the 1990s, the Research Center for Ancient Sculpture of the University of Cologne systematically began to digitize its photo archive and thus also prints based on negatives of the DAI. Soon after, projects for systematic digitization began, following digitization projects in the Archives. Examples include the DFG-funded projects EMAGINES and the digitization of drawings, plans and constructions of the 19th and 20th century in the German Archaeological Institute in Rome. Further projects within the program for the preservation of cultural heritage and the project "Zero Hour - a future for the post-crisis" were supported by the Federal Foreign Office. Today, the archives are systematically digitized at all departments of the DAI.
